Malaysia at the 2023 ASEAN Para Games

The 2023 ASEAN Para Games, officially known as the 12th ASEAN Para Games, is a multi-sport event for Southeast Asian athletes with physical disabilities. The games will be held in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, from June 3 to June 9, 2023. Malaysia will be participating in the games, sending a contingent of athletes to compete in various sports. This article provides an overview of Malaysia's participation in the 2023 ASEAN Para Games, including the medal summary, medalists, and performance in each sport.

#Medal summary

Malaysia's athletes have won a total of 39 medals, consisting of 15 gold, 13 silver, and 11 bronze medals.

##Medal by sport

Malaysia's medals were won in the following sports:

* Athletics: 8 medals (3 gold, 3 silver, 2 bronze)
* Badminton: 2 medals (1 gold, 1 silver)
* Blind Football: 1 medal (1 bronze)
* Boccia: 2 medals (1 silver, 1 bronze)
* Chess: 2 medals (2 gold)

article:
Barry Humphries
================

Barry Humphries AO, CBE (1934-2023) was an Australian comedian, actor, satirist, artist, and author. He is best known for his on-stage and television alter egos, particularly his drag character Dame Edna Everage, a Melbourne housewife-turned-megastar, and Sir Les Patterson, a boorish Australian diplomat.

Early life
-----------

Barry Humphries was born on February 17, 1934, in Camberwell, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. He was the second of three children to Eric and Lou Humphries. His father was a construction manager and his mother was a property manager.

### Education

Humphries attended Melbourne Grammar School, where he began to develop his skills as a comedian and actor. After completing his secondary education, he studied law at the University of Melbourne, but he did not graduate. Instead, he pursued a career in the arts.

Career
--------

### Early career in Australia

Humphries began his career in the 1950s as a comedian and actor in Melbourne's theater scene. He was a member of the Melbourne Theatre Company and appeared in numerous productions, including the Australian premiere of Samuel Beckett's "Waiting for Godot." In the late 1950s, he moved to Sydney, where he became a regular performer on Australian television.

### London and the 1960s

In 1959, Humphries moved to London, where he became a key figure in the city's satire boom of the 1960s. He was a founding member of the Establishment Club, a satire club that also featured performers such as Peter Cook and Dudley Moore. During this period, he developed his character of Dame Edna Everage, a suburban Melbourne housewife who would become his most famous alter ego.

### 1970s

In the 1970s, Humphries' career took off, both in Australia and internationally. He appeared in numerous television shows, including "The Barry Humphries Show" and "The Dame Edna Experience." He also began to tour the world with his one-man shows, which featured his characters Dame Edna and Sir Les Patterson.

### Film roles

Humphries has appeared in numerous films throughout his career, including "Bedazzled" (1967), "The Bliss of Mrs. Blossom" (1968), and "The Great Macarthy" (1975). He has also had roles in several Australian films, including "The Wackiest Wagon Train in the West" (1976) and "The Getting of Wisdom" (1977).

### One-man shows

Humphries has toured the world with numerous one-man shows, including "A Night with Dame Edna" (1979), "The Dame Edna Experience" (1987), and "Eat Pray Laugh!" (2009). His shows typically feature a mix of comedy, music, and drama, and often include audience participation.

### Television roles

Humphries has appeared in numerous television shows throughout his career, including "The Barry Humphries Show" (1967), "The Dame Edna Experience" (1987), and "Da Kath and Kim Code" (2005). He has also made guest appearances on shows such as "The Simpsons" and "Neighbours."

### Success in the United States

In the 1970s and 1980s, Humphries achieved significant success in the United States, particularly with his character Dame Edna. He appeared on numerous television shows, including "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson" and "Saturday Night Live." He also toured the country with his one-man shows, which were often sold out.

### Farewell tour

In 2012, Humphries announced that he would be retiring his character Dame Edna and embarking on a farewell tour. The tour, which was called "Eat Pray Laugh!," visited numerous cities around the world and featured a mix of comedy, music, and drama.

### Weimar Cabaret

In recent years, Humphries has become fascinated with the Weimar Republic and its cabaret culture. He has performed in numerous Weimar-themed shows, including "Weimar Cabaret" (2013) and "The Berlin Kabarett" (2015). These shows have featured a mix of music, comedy, and drama, and have often included audience participation.

Characters
----------

### Dame Edna Everage

Dame Edna Everage is Humphries' most famous alter ego. She is a suburban Melbourne housewife who has become a megastar. The character was created in the 1950s and has since become a cultural icon in Australia and around the world. Dame Edna is known for her outrageous costumes, her sharp wit, and her ability to poke fun at herself and others.

### Sir Les Patterson

Sir Les Patterson is another of Humphries' famous alter egos. He is a boorish Australian diplomat who is known for his sexist and racist attitudes. The character was created in the 1970s and has since become a cult figure in Australia and around the world. Sir Les is known for his outrageous behavior and his ability to offend those around him.

### Sandy Stone

Sandy Stone is a lesser-known alter ego of Humphries. He is a quiet, unassuming Australian who is known for his dry wit and his ability to observe the world around him. The character was created in the 1960s and has since appeared in numerous shows and films.

Personal life
-------------

### Views on transgenderism

In recent years, Humphries has been criticized for his views on transgenderism. In 2016, he sparked controversy when he said that he did not believe that Caitlyn Jenner was a woman. He later clarified his comments, saying that he was simply trying to make a point about the complexity of gender identity.

### Death

Barry Humphries passed away on 22 April 2023, at the age of 89.

Other work
----------

### Bibliography

Humphries has written several books throughout his career, including "Bizarre" (1965), "The Barry Humphries Book of Innocent Austral Verse" (1968), and "My Life As Me" (2002).

### Filmography

Humphries has appeared in numerous films throughout his career, including "Bedazzled" (1967), "The Bliss of Mrs. Blossom" (1968), and "The Great Macarthy" (1975).

### Discography

Humphries has released several albums throughout his career, including "Wild Life in Suburbia" (1964) and "Housewife Superstar" (1976).

### Biographical studies

There have been several biographical studies of Humphries throughout his career, including "The Barry Humphries Story" (1979) and "More Please" (1992).

### Fictional characters

Humphries has created numerous fictional characters throughout his career, including Dame Edna Everage, Sir Les Patterson, and Sandy Stone.

Awards and honours
-------------------

Humphries has won numerous awards throughout his career, including a BAFTA Award, a Tony Award, and an Order of the British Empire. He has also been recognized for his contributions to the arts, including being named an Officer of the Order of Australia.

article:
RRR

RRR is a 2022 Indian Telugu-language period action drama film written and directed by S. S. Rajamouli. The film stars N. T. Rama Rao Jr., Ram Charan, Alia Bhatt, and Olivia Morris in key roles. Set in the 1920s, the film is a fictionalized account of the lives of two Indian revolutionaries, Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem, who fought against the British Raj and the Nizam of Hyderabad.

#Plot

The film opens in 1920s India, where the British are ruling the country with an iron fist. The story revolves around two young men, Komaram Bheem (N. T. Rama Rao Jr.) and Alluri Sitarama Raju (Ram Charan), who are from different parts of the country but share a common goal of fighting for India's independence. Bheem is a Gond tribal leader who lives in the forests of Adilabad, while Raju is a police officer in the British Indian Army.

The two men meet in Delhi, where Bheem is on a mission to rescue a young girl from his tribe who has been kidnapped by the British. Raju, who is initially working for the British, joins forces with Bheem to help him complete his mission. As they spend more time together, they realize that they have a common enemy in the British and decide to join forces to fight for India's freedom.

The rest of the film follows their journey as they take on the British and the Nizam of Hyderabad, who are determined to crush their rebellion. Along the way, they meet other characters, including Sita (Alia Bhatt) and Jenny (Olivia Morris), who join their fight for freedom.

#Cast

* N. T. Rama Rao Jr. as Komaram Bheem
* Ram Charan as Alluri Sitarama Raju
* Alia Bhatt as Sita
* Olivia Morris as Jenny
* Ajay Devgn as Venkata Rama Raju
* Shriya Saran as Sarojini
* Samuthirakani as Venkat Reddy
* Ray Stevenson as Governor Scott Buxton
* Alison Doody as Lady Scott Buxton
* Chatrapathi Sekhar as Jangu

#Production

##Development

RRR was first announced in 2018, when S. S. Rajamouli revealed that he was working on a new film with N. T. Rama Rao Jr. and Ram Charan. The film was initially titled "Rama Ravana Rajyam" but was later changed to RRR. Rajamouli spent several months researching the lives of Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem, who were two real-life Indian revolutionaries.

##Casting

The casting process for RRR was extensive, with Rajamouli holding auditions for several months. N. T. Rama Rao Jr. and Ram Charan were the first two actors to be cast in the film. Alia Bhatt and Olivia Morris were later cast as the female leads.

##Design

The film's production design was handled by Sabu Cyril, who created elaborate sets to depict the 1920s era. The costume design was handled by Srinivas Morya, who created costumes that were inspired by the clothing of the time period.

##Principal photography

Principal photography for RRR began in November 2018 and lasted for over two years. The film was shot in various locations across India, including Hyderabad, Delhi, and Mumbai.

##Post-production

The post-production process for RRR was handled by A. Sreekar Prasad, who edited the film. The visual effects were handled by V. Srinivas Mohan, who created elaborate action sequences and CGI effects.

#Themes and influences

RRR explores several themes, including patriotism, freedom, and friendship. The film is heavily influenced by Indian mythology and history, with Rajamouli drawing inspiration from the lives of Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem.

#Music

The music for RRR was composed by M. M. Keeravani, who created a soundtrack that was inspired by Indian folk music. The film's score was also composed by Keeravani, who created a sweeping score that incorporated traditional Indian instruments.

#Marketing

The marketing campaign for RRR was extensive, with the film's trailer being released in several languages. The film's promotional materials, including posters and TV spots, were also widely released.

#Release

##Theatrical

RRR was released theatrically on March 25, 2022, in several languages, including Telugu, Tamil, Hindi, and Malayalam.

##Screenings and statistics

RRR was screened in over 10,000 theaters worldwide, making it one of the widest releases in Indian cinema history. The film grossed over ₹700 crore in its opening weekend, making it one of the highest-grossing opening weekends in Indian cinema history.

##Distribution

RRR was distributed by several companies, including DVV Entertainment, Pen Studios, and Lyca Productions.

##Home media

RRR was released on home media platforms, including DVD, Blu-ray, and digital streaming platforms, in June 2022.

#Critical reception

##India

RRR received widespread critical acclaim in India, with many praising the film's direction, performances, and action sequences.

##International

RRR also received positive reviews from international critics, with many praising the film's visuals, music, and performances.

#Reception by international filmmakers

RRR was praised by several international filmmakers, including James Cameron and Steven Spielberg.

#Box office

RRR was a major commercial success, grossing over ₹1,000 crore worldwide.

#Impact

RRR had a significant impact on Indian cinema, with many praising the film's ambitious scope and technical achievements.

#Accolades

RRR won several awards, including the National Film Award for Best Popular Film Providing Wholesome Entertainment.

#Adaptations

There have been reports of a possible sequel to RRR, although nothing has been officially announced.

#Future

RRR is widely regarded as one of the greatest Indian films of all time, and its success is likely to inspire a new generation of Indian filmmakers.

* List of highest-grossing Indian films
* List of most expensive Indian films
* Indian cinema

#Notes

* RRR is the first Indian film to gross over ₹1,000 crore worldwide.
* RRR is the highest-grossing Telugu film of all time.

UAAP Season 85 Volleyball Tournaments

The UAAP Season 85 volleyball tournaments commenced on February 25, 2023, at the SM Mall of Asia Arena in Pasay, Philippines. The tournament featured eight teams from different universities, competing in men's, women's, boys', and girls' divisions. The season marked the return of the UAAP volleyball tournaments after a two-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

# Tournament format

The tournament format for the UAAP Season 85 volleyball tournaments consisted of a single round-robin elimination round, followed by a stepladder semifinals for the men's and women's divisions, and a semifinals for the boys' and girls' divisions. The top four teams in each division qualified for the playoffs, with the top two teams earning a twice-to-beat advantage in the semifinals.

# Teams

## Name changes

* National University's (NU) men's and women's teams were rebranded as the "NU Bulldogs" and "NU Lady Bulldogs", respectively.

## Coaching changes

* University of Santo Tomas (UST) appointed Carmela Acevedo as the new head coach of the UST Golden Tigresses.

article:
Leonardo Torres Quevedo

Leonardo Torres Quevedo (1852-1936) was a Spanish engineer and mathematician, best known for his innovative work in the fields of automation, analogue computing, and aerostatics. He is considered one of the pioneers of modern robotics and artificial intelligence. Throughout his life, Torres Quevedo was driven by a passion for science and technology, and his contributions to various fields have had a lasting impact on the development of modern engineering and computer science.

#Early life and education

Leonardo Torres Quevedo was born on December 28, 1852, in Santa Cruz de Iber, a small town in the province of Burgos, Spain. His family was of modest means, but his parents encouraged his interest in science and mathematics from an early age. Torres Quevedo began his education at the local school in Santa Cruz, where he showed a particular aptitude for mathematics. He later moved to the Colegio de San Nicolás in Burgos, where he continued his studies in mathematics and science.

In 1870, Torres Quevedo enrolled in the University of Valladolid, where he studied civil engineering. He graduated in 1876, and soon began working as a civil engineer on various projects in Spain. However, his true passion lay in mathematics and science, and he continued to study and work on various projects in his spare time.

#Career

##Cableways

Torres Quevedo's early career as a civil engineer led him to work on various projects, including the design and construction of cableways. In the late 19th century, cableways were a common means of transporting goods and people over long distances, particularly in mountainous regions. Torres Quevedo's work on cableways led him to develop innovative solutions to the technical challenges involved, including the design of more efficient cable systems and the development of new materials.

##Analogue calculating machines

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Torres Quevedo became increasingly interested in the development of analogue calculating machines. These machines used mechanical or electromechanical components to perform mathematical calculations, and were precursors to modern digital computers. Torres Quevedo's work on analogue calculating machines led him to develop a range of innovative devices, including machines that could perform arithmetic operations, solve differential equations, and even play chess.

##Aerostatics

Torres Quevedo was also fascinated by aerostatics, the study of the behavior of gases in equilibrium. He developed a range of innovative devices, including airships and dirigibles, and even designed a system for navigating airships using gyroscopes.

##Radio control: the Telekino

In 1903, Torres Quevedo developed the Telekino, a system for controlling machines remotely using radio signals. The Telekino was a pioneering achievement in the field of robotics, and laid the foundation for modern radio control systems.

##Formal language

Torres Quevedo was also interested in the development of formal languages, which are used to describe the syntax and semantics of programming languages. He developed a range of formal languages, including one that was used to describe the behavior of his analogue calculating machines.

##Laboratory of Automation

In 1912, Torres Quevedo established the Laboratory of Automation in Madrid, which became a hub for research and development in automation and robotics. The laboratory was equipped with a range of innovative devices, including robots, automated machines, and analogue calculating machines.

##Chess automaton: El Ajedrecista

In 1912, Torres Quevedo developed El Ajedrecista, a chess-playing automaton that could play a game of chess against a human opponent. El Ajedrecista was a pioneering achievement in the field of artificial intelligence, and demonstrated the potential of machines to perform complex tasks.

##Essays on Automatics

Torres Quevedo wrote a range of essays on automatics, which were published in various journals and books. His essays covered topics such as the history of automation, the development of analogue calculating machines, and the potential applications of automation in industry and society.

###Analytical machines

Torres Quevedo was particularly interested in the development of analytical machines, which were designed to perform complex mathematical calculations. He developed a range of analytical machines, including ones that could solve differential equations and perform arithmetic operations.

##Naval projects

Torres Quevedo also worked on various naval projects, including the design and construction of submarines and torpedoes. He developed a range of innovative solutions to the technical challenges involved, including the use of gyroscopes and radio control systems.

##Other inventions and miscellaneous activities

Torres Quevedo was a prolific inventor and developed a range of other innovative devices and systems, including a machine that could transmit images over wires, a system for navigating ships using gyroscopes, and a range of medical devices.

###Esperantist

Torres Quevedo was also an Esperantist, and believed that the Esperanto language could be used as a universal language for international communication. He wrote several articles and books on Esperanto, and even developed a range of Esperanto-language teaching materials.

###Spanish-American Technological Dictionary

Torres Quevedo also compiled the Spanish-American Technological Dictionary, which was a comprehensive dictionary of technical terms used in industry and engineering.

#Distinctions

Torres Quevedo received a range of distinctions and awards for his contributions to science and technology. He was elected to the Spanish Royal Academy of Sciences in 1901, and received the Grand Cross of the Order of Isabella the Catholic in 1920.

#Personal life, religious beliefs and death

Torres Quevedo was a devout Catholic, and believed that his work in science and technology was a way of serving God. He was married to Maria de los Ángeles González, and had five children. He died on December 18, 1936, at the age of 83, and was buried in the Cementerio de la Almudena in Madrid.

#Legacy

Torres Quevedo's legacy is a testament to his innovative spirit and his contributions to science and technology. He is remembered as one of the pioneers of modern robotics and artificial intelligence, and his work continues to inspire new generations of scientists and engineers.

#In fiction

Torres Quevedo has been the subject of several works of fiction, including a novel by the Spanish author, Javier Benet. The novel, " Torres Quevedo: El inventor de la era moderna", tells the story of Torres Quevedo's life and work, and explores the themes of science, technology, and innovation.

Aryan Valley
================

The Aryan Valley is a scenic and culturally significant region located in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. It is situated in the Kargil district, approximately 70 kilometers southeast of the town of Kargil. The valley is nestled in the Himalayas, surrounded by towering mountains and picturesque landscapes. The Aryan Valley is not only a natural wonder but also a culturally rich and historically significant area, with a unique blend of Tibetan and Indian influences.

Geography and Economy
----------------------

The Aryan Valley is a relatively remote and inaccessible region, with limited connectivity to the rest of the world. The valley is surrounded by the Himalayan mountain range, with steep cliffs and deep gorges. The terrain is rugged, with rocky outcrops, snow-capped peaks, and alpine meadows. The valley floor is narrow, with a few villages and hamlets scattered along the riverbanks.

The economy of the Aryan Valley is primarily based on agriculture and animal husbandry. The region is known for its high-quality wool, which is obtained from the local sheep and goats. The valley is also home to a variety of crops, including barley, wheat, and potatoes. The region's harsh climate and limited connectivity make it difficult to access markets and sell products, resulting in a relatively subsistence-based economy.

History
--------

The Aryan Valley has a rich and diverse history, with various cultures and empires vying for control over the region. The valley has been inhabited by the Brokpa community, an indigenous tribe with a unique culture and language.

### Brokpas

The Brokpas are an ancient tribe that inhabits the Aryan Valley. They are believed to be the descendants of the Dard people, who lived in the region thousands of years ago. The Brokpas have a unique culture, language, and customs, which are distinct from the rest of the Indian subcontinent. They are predominantly Buddhist, with a strong emphasis on Tibetan Buddhism.

The Brokpas have a rich tradition of storytelling, music, and dance. They are skilled craftsmen, known for their expertise in woolen products, such as shawls, hats, and socks. The Brokpas are also expert farmers, with a deep understanding of the local soil and climate.

### Aryan Association and Neologism

In recent years, the term "Aryan" has been associated with the valley, leading to a neologism that has sparked controversy and debate. The term "Aryan" is derived from the Sanskrit word "arya," meaning "noble" or "exalted." The term has been used to describe the Indo-European people who migrated to the Indian subcontinent thousands of years ago.

However, the association of the term "Aryan" with the valley is a relatively recent phenomenon, dating back to the early 20th century. Some scholars argue that the term was used to describe the valley's unique cultural and linguistic heritage, while others argue that it was used to promote a nationalist and racial agenda.

The controversy surrounding the term "Aryan" has led to a reevaluation of the valley's history and cultural identity. Many scholars argue that the term is a misnomer, and that the valley's unique culture and language are better described by the term "Brokpa."

Eiji Tsuburaya

Eiji Tsuburaya was a Japanese filmmaker, special effects director, and producer who is best known for his work on the Godzilla franchise and the Ultraman series. Born on July 7, 1901, in Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan, Tsuburaya was a pioneering figure in the Japanese film industry, particularly in the fields of science fiction and tokusatsu (special effects).

# Biography

## Childhood to war years: 1901–1945

### Childhood and youth (1901–1919)

Eiji Tsuburaya was born to a family of modest means in Sukagawa, Fukushima. His father was a Buddhist priest, and his mother was a homemaker. Tsuburaya's early life was marked by a love of animals and the outdoors, which would later influence his filmmaking style. He attended local schools and developed an interest in photography and filmmaking.

### Early career and marriage (1919–1934)

In 1919, Tsuburaya moved to Tokyo to pursue a career in filmmaking. He began working as a cinematographer's assistant at the Nikkatsu film studio, where he met his future wife, Masano Araki. The couple married in 1923 and had two children, a son named Toshio and a daughter named Yuriko.

In 1934, Tsuburaya joined J.O. Studios, where he worked as a special effects director on several films. His early work in this field was influenced by the American filmmaker Willis O'Brien, who had worked on the classic film "The Lost World" (1925). Tsuburaya's own directorial debut came in 1936 with the film "The Daughter of the Samurai." He continued to work as a special effects director and director throughout the 1930s, eventually joining Toho Studios in 1940.

During World War II, Tsuburaya was drafted into the Japanese military and served as a cameraman for the Imperial Japanese Army. He was stationed in China and the Philippines, where he filmed military operations and propaganda films. After Japan's defeat in World War II, Tsuburaya returned to Toho Studios and resumed his work as a special effects director. 2022 United States Senate election in Georgia
=============================================

The 2022 United States Senate election in Georgia was held on November 8, 2022, to elect a member of the United States Senate to represent the state of Georgia. The election was a rematch of the 2020 special election, with Democratic incumbent Raphael Warnock facing off against Republican challenger Herschel Walker.

Democratic primary
-----------------

### Candidates

#### Nominee

* Raphael Warnock, incumbent U.S. Senator

#### Eliminated in primary

* Tamara Johnson-Shealey, Smyrna city councilor
* Kelvin King, pastor and candidate for the U.S. Senate in 2020

Warnock was endorsed by several high-profile Democrats, including President Joe Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris, and former President Barack Obama.

### Polling

Warnock was heavily favored to win the primary, and polls consistently showed him leading Johnson-Shealey by wide margins.

### Results

Warnock won the primary with over 96% of the vote, with Johnson-Shealey receiving just over 3%.

Republican primary
-----------------

#### Nominee

* Herschel Walker, former NFL player and candidate for the U.S. Senate in 2020

#### Eliminated in primary

#### Declined

* Brian Kemp, Governor of Georgia

### Debates

The Republican primary candidates participated in several debates, including one hosted by the Atlanta Press Club and another hosted by the Georgia Republican Party.

### Endorsements

Walker was endorsed by former President Donald Trump, who had encouraged him to run for the seat.

Walker led the polls throughout the primary campaign, with Black and Saddler trailing behind.

----------------

### Debates

The general election candidates participated in several debates, including one hosted by the Atlanta Press Club and another hosted by the Georgia Public Broadcasting.

### Endorsements

Warnock was endorsed by several prominent Democrats, including President Biden and Vice President Harris. Walker was endorsed by former President Trump and the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

### Polling

The polls were closely divided throughout the campaign, with Warnock leading Walker by small margins.

### Results

Warnock won the general election with just over 51% of the vote, with Walker receiving just over 49%.

#### By congressional district

Warnock won several congressional districts that had voted Republican in the 2020 presidential election, including the 6th and 7th districts.

#### Voter demographics

St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery
=====================================

St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery is a historic Orthodox Christian monastery located in the heart of Kiev, Ukraine. The monastery is situated on a hill overlooking the Dnieper River and is one of the city's most iconic landmarks. The monastery has a rich history dating back to the 12th century and has played a significant role in the development of Ukrainian culture and spirituality.

History
--------

### Early years

The monastery was founded in 1108-1113 by Sviatopolk II Iziaslavich, the Grand Prince of Kiev, who built the first wooden church on the site. The church was dedicated to the Archangel Michael, the patron saint of Kiev. The monastery quickly gained prominence as a center of learning, art, and spirituality, attracting monks and pilgrims from all over Eastern Europe.

### 16th–17th centuries

During the 16th and 17th centuries, the monastery underwent significant transformations. In 1496, the monastery was rebuilt in stone, and the iconic golden domes were added to the church. The monastery became a major center of Ukrainian Orthodox culture, producing many prominent scholars, artists, and theologians. The monastery's scriptorium was renowned for its illuminated manuscripts, and its workshops produced intricate icons and frescoes.

### 18th century

In the 18th century, the monastery experienced a period of decline, due in part to the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth's attempts to suppress Ukrainian culture. However, the monastery continued to play an important role in Ukrainian society, serving as a center of education and a symbol of national identity.

### 19th century

During the 19th century, the monastery underwent significant restoration work, including the rebuilding of the church's golden domes. The monastery also became a major center of Ukrainian nationalism, with many prominent writers, artists, and politicians drawn to its cultural and spiritual significance.

### 20th century

In the early 20th century, the monastery was nationalized by the Soviet government, and its monks were forced to flee or go into hiding. The monastery's buildings were converted into a museum, and many of its artworks and artifacts were sold or destroyed. In 1935, the Soviet government demolished the monastery's church, citing its "decadent" and "reactionary" architecture.

### Demolition and aftermath

The demolition of the monastery's church was a devastating blow to Ukrainian culture and identity. Many of the monastery's artworks and artifacts were lost or destroyed, and the site was left abandoned and neglected. However, the monastery's legacy continued to inspire Ukrainian nationalists and dissidents, who saw it as a symbol of resistance against Soviet oppression.

### Restoration

In the late 1980s, with the advent of glasnost and perestroika, the Ukrainian government began to restore the monastery. The restoration project was a massive undertaking, involving the rebuilding of the church, the refectory, and other buildings.

#### Plans and preparatory work

The restoration project began with a thorough examination of the site and the remaining buildings. Archaeologists and historians worked to reconstruct the monastery's original layout and architecture, using historical records and surviving artifacts.

#### Rebuilding the monastery

The rebuilding of the monastery began in the early 1990s, with the construction of the new church. The church was designed to replicate the original 11th-century structure, using traditional materials and techniques. The golden domes were rebuilt, and the interior was adorned with intricate frescoes and mosaics.

#### Metropolitan see

In 1999, the monastery was designated as the metropolitan see of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate). The monastery's abbot, Metropolitan Onuphrius, was enthroned as the primate of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church.

Architecture
------------

### Dates, styles and architects

The monastery's architecture reflects its complex and evolving history. The original 11th-century church was built in the Byzantine style, with a central dome and four smaller domes. The 16th-century rebuilding of the church introduced Renaissance elements, including the iconic golden domes. The 19th-century restoration work added Neoclassical elements, including the refectory's facade.

### Cathedral (11th–20th century structure)

The original 11th-century church was a small, single-domed structure. Over the centuries, the church was expanded and modified, with the addition of new domes and chapels. The church's interior was adorned with intricate frescoes and mosaics, including a famous 12th-century mosaic of the Archangel Michael.

### Rebuilt cathedral

The rebuilt cathedral is a faithful replica of the original 11th-century structure, with some modifications to accommodate modern needs. The church's exterior is adorned with intricate stone carvings and ornate metalwork.

#### Exterior

The church's exterior is dominated by the five golden domes, which are topped with ornate metalwork and finials. The facade is adorned with intricate stone carvings, including a famous 19th-century relief of the Archangel Michael.

#### Interior

The church's interior is adorned with intricate frescoes and mosaics, including a famous 12th-century mosaic of the Archangel Michael. The iconostasis is a masterpiece of Ukrainian Baroque, with intricate carvings and gilded ornaments.

### Refectory

The refectory is a large, rectangular building with a Neoclassical facade. The interior is adorned with intricate frescoes and mosaics, including a famous 19th-century mural of the Last Supper.

### Other buildings

The monastery complex includes several other buildings, including the abbot's residence, the monks' quarters, and the scriptorium.

#### Rebuilt bell tower

The bell tower is a separate structure, located near the church. The tower is adorned with intricate stone carvings and ornate metalwork, and is topped with a large, golden cross.

Cathedral artworks (pre-1935)
---------------------------

### Interior elements

The cathedral's interior was adorned with numerous artworks, including frescoes, mosaics, and icons.

#### Frescoes

The cathedral's walls and ceilings were adorned with intricate frescoes, depicting scenes from the Bible and the lives of saints. Many of the frescoes were created by famous Ukrainian artists, including the 19th-century master, Taras Shevchenko.

#### Mosaics

The cathedral's interior was also adorned with intricate mosaics, including a famous 12th-century mosaic of the Archangel Michael. Many of the mosaics were created by famous Ukrainian artists, including the 19th-century master, Taras Shevchenko.

### Relics of St. Barbara

The cathedral housed a famous relic of St. Barbara, a 4th-century martyr and saint. The relic was a fragment of the saint's skull, which was encased in a ornate, gilded reliquary.

### Iconostasis

The iconostasis was a masterpiece of Ukrainian Baroque, with intricate carvings and gilded ornaments. The iconostasis was adorned with numerous icons, including a famous 18th-century icon of the Virgin Mary.

### Other notable artworks

The cathedral housed numerous other artworks, including a famous 19th-century mural of the Last Supper, and a collection of intricate, 16th-century illuminated manuscripts.

The monastery's library housed a vast collection of books and documents, including rare, 16th-century manuscripts and early printed books.

EuroBasket Women 2023

The EuroBasket Women 2023 is the 39th edition of the EuroBasket Women championship, which is the main international basketball competition for women's national teams in Europe. The tournament was held from June 15 to June 25, 2023, in Israel and Slovenia.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the EuroBasket Women 2023 started in 2019, and several countries expressed their interest in hosting the tournament. After a thorough evaluation, FIBA Europe announced that Israel and Slovenia would co-host the tournament. This was the first time that two countries would co-host the EuroBasket Women championship.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the EuroBasket Women 2023 started in November 2021 and ended in February 2023. A total of 38 teams participated in the qualification process, and the top 16 teams qualified for the tournament.

## Qualified teams

The following 16 teams qualified for the EuroBasket Women 2023:

1.  Belgium
2.  Bosnia and Herzegovina

3.  Arena Stožice (Ljubljana, Slovenia)
4.  Tivoli Hall (Ljubljana, Slovenia)

# Draw

The draw for the EuroBasket Women 2023 took place on March 8, 2023, in Munich, Germany. The 16 teams were divided into four groups of four teams each.

## Seedings

The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous edition of the EuroBasket Women championship. The seedings were as follows:

# Squads

# Preliminary round

The preliminary round was held from June 15 to June 18, 2023. The teams were divided into four groups of four teams each, and each team played the other teams in their group once.

## Group A

Group A consisted of Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, and France. France won all their games in the group and topped the table.

## Group B

article:
Embassy without a Government

An embassy without a government refers to a diplomatic mission that continues to operate and function despite the absence or collapse of the government it represents. This phenomenon has occurred throughout history, often as a result of war, revolution, or regime change. In such cases, the embassy may continue to provide services to its citizens, engage in diplomatic activities, and even represent the interests of the defunct government.

# History

## Russia (1917–1925)

The Russian Revolution of 1917 led to the overthrow of the Romanov dynasty and the establishment of the Soviet Union. However, the diplomatic missions of the Russian Empire continued to operate abroad, albeit in a state of limbo.

### Diplomatic missions after 1917

Following the revolution, many Russian diplomats abroad refused to recognize the new Soviet government, instead opting to continue representing the interests of the deposed monarchy. This led to a situation where multiple Russian diplomatic missions coexisted, each claiming to represent the legitimate government of Russia. The Soviet government, meanwhile, established its own diplomatic missions, which gradually gained recognition from other countries.

The most notable example of an embassy without a government during this period was the Russian Embassy in Paris, which continued to operate under the auspices of the deposed monarchy. The embassy's staff, led by Ambassador Vasily Maklakov, refused to recognize the Soviet government and instead maintained ties with the Russian émigré community. The embassy's activities were tolerated by the French government, which saw it as a means of maintaining relations with the Russian people, even if not with the Soviet government.

### Dissolution of the Soviet Union

The situation was eventually resolved with the establishment of formal diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and other countries. The Russian Embassy in Paris, along with other diplomatic missions representing the deposed monarchy, was gradually dismantled, and its staff either retired or defected to the Soviet government.

## Spain (1939–1977)

The Spanish Civil War led to the establishment of a fascist dictatorship under General Francisco Franco, which lasted until his death in 1975. During this period, the Second Spanish Republic, which had been overthrown by Franco's forces, maintained a diplomatic mission in exile.

### Diplomatic missions after 1939

The government-in-exile, led by President Manuel Azaña, established a network of diplomatic missions abroad, which continued to represent the interests of the deposed republic. These missions operated in a state of limbo, as they were not recognized by the Franco regime or by most other countries. Despite this, the missions continued to provide services to Spanish citizens abroad and engaged in diplomatic activities, including efforts to isolate the Franco regime.

The most notable example of an embassy without a government during this period was the Spanish Embassy in Mexico City, which served as the de facto capital of the government-in-exile. The embassy's staff, led by Ambassador Félix Gordón Ordás, maintained close ties with the Mexican government, which provided significant support to the Republican cause.

## Poland (1939–1990)

The invasion of Poland by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union in 1939 led to the establishment of a Polish government-in-exile, which operated in London and later in Paris.

### Diplomatic missions after 1939

The government-in-exile established a network of diplomatic missions abroad, which continued to represent the interests of Poland despite the absence of a recognized Polish government. These missions operated in a state of limbo, as they were not recognized by the occupying powers or by many other countries. Despite this, the missions continued to provide services to Polish citizens abroad and engaged in diplomatic activities, including efforts to secure support for the Polish resistance.

The most notable example of an embassy without a government during this period was the Polish Embassy in Washington, D.C., which served as a key center for Polish-American relations. The embassy's staff, led by Ambassador Jan Ciechanowski, maintained close ties with the U.S. government, which provided significant support to the Polish cause.

## Afghanistan (2021–present)

The Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan in August 2021 led to the collapse of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, which had been established in 2001.

### Diplomatic missions after 2021

The diplomatic missions of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan continued to operate abroad, despite the absence of a recognized government. These missions, including the Afghan Embassy in Washington, D.C., have maintained ties with the international community and continued to provide services to Afghan citizens abroad. However, the Taliban's takeover has led to a situation where multiple Afghan diplomatic missions coexist, each claiming to represent the legitimate government of Afghanistan.

The international community has been slow to recognize the Taliban's government, and many countries have instead maintained ties with the diplomatic missions of the deposed Islamic Republic. This has led to a situation where the Afghan Embassy in Washington, D.C., continues to operate under the auspices of the deposed government, even as the Taliban's government seeks to establish its own diplomatic presence abroad.

article:
2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification

The 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification was the qualification process for the 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup, the fourth edition of the AFC U-23 Asian Cup, the biennial international youth football championship organized by the Asian Football Confederation (AFC) for the men's under-23 national teams of Asia. A total of 44 teams entered the qualification process, competing for 15 spots in the final tournament, with Uzbekistan qualifying automatically as hosts.

#Format changes

Compared to previous editions, the qualification process has been modified to include more teams and more matches. The number of participating teams has been increased from 38 to 44, and the qualification process now consists of two rounds, with the first round featuring 10 groups of 4 teams each, and the second round featuring 5 groups of 3 teams each. The top team from each group in the second round will qualify for the final tournament, along with the best second-placed team.

#Draw

The draw for the qualification process took place on 2 June 2023 at the AFC House in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The 44 teams were drawn into 10 groups of 4 teams each, with the teams seeded based on their performance in the 2022 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification and the 2022 FIFA World Cup qualification.

##Draw result

The draw resulted in the following groups:

* Group A: China PR, Malaysia, Laos, Singapore
* Group B: Japan, Vietnam, Philippines, Timor-Leste
* Group C: South Korea, Thailand, Cambodia, Brunei
* Group D: Australia, Indonesia, Myanmar, Macau
* Group E: Saudi Arabia, India, Kuwait, Bangladesh
* Group F: United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Yemen, Bhutan
* Group G: Iran, Qatar, Turkmenistan, Nepal
* Group H: Iraq, Palestine, Oman, Maldives
* Group I: Uzbekistan (hosts), Bahrain, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan
* Group J: North Korea, Chinese Taipei, Hong Kong, Guam
* Group K: Syria, Lebanon, Mongolia, Pakistan

#Format

The qualification process will consist of two rounds. The first round will feature 10 groups of 4 teams each, with the teams playing each other on a home-and-away basis. The top two teams from each group will advance to the second round, along with the best third-placed team.

##Tiebreakers

In the event of a tie between two or more teams, the following tiebreakers will be used:

* Points earned in head-to-head matches between the tied teams
* Goal difference in head-to-head matches between the tied teams
* Goals scored in head-to-head matches between the tied teams
* Goal difference in all group matches
* Goals scored in all group matches

2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup

The 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup is the 23rd edition of the FIFA U-20 World Cup, the biennial international men's youth football championship contested by the under-20 national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The tournament is scheduled to take place in Argentina from May 20 to June 11, 2023.

#Host selection

The bidding process for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup was launched by FIFA in June 2019. A total of four countries expressed interest in hosting the tournament: Argentina, Indonesia, Peru, and Uruguay. Indonesia was initially awarded the hosting rights on October 24, 2019, but due to protests and concerns over the country's ability to host the tournament, FIFA announced on March 29, 2023, that Argentina would replace Indonesia as the host.

#Qualified teams

A total of 24 teams qualified for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup. The qualified teams are:

* Africa: Egypt, Nigeria, Senegal, Tunisia
* Asia: Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Uzbekistan

#Group stage

article:
FTX
=====

FTX was a cryptocurrency derivatives exchange that was launched in 2019 and was one of the largest and most popular exchanges in the world until its collapse in November 2022. FTX was known for its innovative products, high liquidity, and celebrity endorsements, but its rapid growth and success ultimately led to a catastrophic crisis that sent shockwaves throughout the cryptocurrency industry.

History
-------

FTX was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried, a young entrepreneur and trader who had previously worked at Jane Street, a quantitative trading firm. Bankman-Fried, also known as SBF, had a vision to create a cryptocurrency exchange that would offer more advanced trading products and better liquidity than existing exchanges. He assembled a team of experienced traders and developers, and FTX quickly gained popularity among professional traders and institutions.

In 2020, FTX raised $8 million in funding from investors, including Binance, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the world. The investment helped FTX expand its operations and develop new products, including perpetual swaps and options. FTX also launched a series of high-profile partnerships with sports teams and celebrities, including the Miami Heat and the NFL's Tom Brady.

November 2022 Crisis and Bankruptcy
------------------------------------

### Background: FTX and Alameda, Binance, and CoinDesk report

In November 2022, a series of events led to the collapse of FTX and its affiliated companies. On November 2, CoinDesk, a cryptocurrency news outlet, published a report that revealed close ties between FTX and Alameda Research, a trading firm also founded by Sam Bankman-Fried. The report raised concerns about the potential for conflicts of interest and the lack of transparency between the two companies.

### Crisis begins: Binance FTT sale, sell-off, and withdrawn rescue bid

On November 6, Binance, FTX's largest investor, announced that it would sell its entire stake in FTX, citing concerns about the company's financial health. The news triggered a massive sell-off of FTX's native token, FTT, which lost over 70% of its value in a matter of hours. As FTT's price plummeted, FTX's liquidity crisis deepened, and the company's ability to meet its obligations to customers and creditors began to deteriorate.

In an effort to rescue FTX, Binance announced on November 8 that it would acquire the company, pending due diligence. However, just 24 hours later, Binance pulled out of the deal, citing concerns about FTX's financial condition and potential regulatory issues.

### Bankruptcy and unauthorized transactions

On November 11, FTX filed for bankruptcy in the United States, along with its affiliated companies, including Alameda Research and FTX.us. The bankruptcy filing revealed that FTX had over $10 billion in liabilities and less than $1 billion in assets.

In the days following the bankruptcy filing, it was discovered that FTX had made unauthorized transactions, including the transfer of millions of dollars in customer funds to Alameda Research. The transactions were allegedly made without the knowledge or consent of FTX's customers, and they have been the subject of intense scrutiny and criticism.

### Widening impact and contagion fears

The collapse of FTX has sent shockwaves throughout the cryptocurrency industry, with many companies and investors feeling the effects of the crisis. Several cryptocurrency exchanges and trading firms have reported losses due to their exposure to FTX, and there are concerns about the potential for contagion and a broader market collapse.

### Responses and effects

#### Effects on investors

The collapse of FTX has resulted in significant losses for many investors, including individual traders and institutional investors. Many investors have reported losing millions of dollars in the collapse, and there are concerns about the potential for widespread financial damage.

#### Effects on other cryptocurrency firms and cryptocurrency markets

The collapse of FTX has also had a significant impact on other cryptocurrency firms and markets. Several exchanges and trading firms have reported losses due to their exposure to FTX, and there are concerns about the potential for contagion and a broader market collapse.

#### Responses and commentary

The collapse of FTX has been met with widespread criticism and condemnation from the cryptocurrency community. Many industry leaders and commentators have called for greater transparency and regulation in the industry, and there are concerns about the potential for future crises.

Legal Process
-------------

The collapse of FTX has triggered a number of legal actions and investigations. In the United States, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) have launched investigations into FTX's activities, and there are reports of potential civil and criminal charges.

2022–23 European windstorm season

The 2022–23 European windstorm season was the sixth instance of seasonal European windstorm naming in Europe. The season began on September 1, 2022, and ended on June 30, 2023. The storms were named by various European meteorological agencies, with the aim of raising public awareness and improving the communication of severe weather forecasts.

# Background and naming

## Definitions and naming conventions

The European windstorm season is a period of time when storms that form in the Atlantic Ocean and move towards Europe are named by various meteorological agencies. The naming conventions are based on a list of names that are chosen by the participating agencies. The names are used to identify the storms and to raise public awareness of the potential impacts of the storms.

## Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland and the Netherlands)

The Western Group, which includes the United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands, uses a list of names that are chosen by the UK Met Office, Met Éireann, and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI). The names are used to identify storms that are forecast to bring strong winds and potentially severe weather to the region.

## South-western Group (France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Luxembourg)

The South-western Group, which includes France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg, uses a list of names that are chosen by Météo-France, the Spanish State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the Portuguese Institute for the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA), the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium (RMI), and the Administration of Technical Services of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg (ASTA). The names are used to identify storms that are forecast to bring strong winds and potentially severe weather to the region.

## Southeastern Mediterranean Group (Greece, Israel and Cyprus)

The Southeastern Mediterranean Group, which includes Greece, Israel, and Cyprus, uses a list of names that are chosen by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service (HNMS), the Israel Meteorological Service (IMS), and the Cyprus Department of Meteorology (CDM). The names are used to identify storms that are forecast to bring strong winds and potentially severe weather to the region.

## Central Mediterranean Group (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Malta)

article:
2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean Cyclone Season

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season is the period of the year when most tropical cyclones form in the South-West Indian Ocean. The season runs from July 1, 2022, to June 30, 2023. This article documents all the storms that formed in this season, as well as their intensity, affected areas, and damage.

# Seasonal forecasts

Before the start of the season, several meteorological agencies issued forecasts predicting the activity of the season. The Mauritius Meteorological Services (MMS) predicted that the season would be near-average to above-average in terms of activity, with 9-11 named storms, 4-5 intense tropical cyclones, and 1-2 very intense tropical cyclones. The South African Weather Service (SAWS) also predicted a near-average season, with 8-10 named storms, 3-4 intense tropical cyclones, and 1 very intense tropical cyclone.

# Seasonal summary

The 2022-23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was marked by above-average activity, with 11 named storms, 5 intense tropical cyclones, and 2 very intense tropical cyclones. The season was also notable for the record-breaking cyclone Freddy, which became the longest-lived tropical cyclone in the South-West Indian Ocean and one of the longest-lived tropical cyclones globally.

# Systems

## Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley

Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley formed on July 23, 2022, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the Mozambique Channel. The system intensified into a moderate tropical storm on July 25, with maximum sustained winds of 60 km/h (37 mph) and a central pressure of 998 hPa (29.47 inHg). Ashley made landfall in southern Mozambique on July 27, causing moderate damage and flooding.

## Moderate Tropical Storm Balita

Moderate Tropical Storm Balita formed on August 2, 2022, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a moderate tropical storm on August 4, with maximum sustained winds of 65 km/h (40 mph) and a central pressure of 994 hPa (29.35 inHg). Balita recurved southward and dissipated on August 7, without affecting any landmasses.

## Tropical Depression 03

Tropical Depression 03 formed on August 12, 2022, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the Mozambique Channel. The system intensified into a tropical depression on August 14, with maximum sustained winds of 55 km/h (34 mph) and a central pressure of 1000 hPa (29.53 inHg). The depression made landfall in northern Mozambique on August 15, causing minimal damage and flooding.

## Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on August 19, 2022, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on August 21, and further into a very intense tropical cyclone on August 24, with maximum sustained winds of 220 km/h (137 mph) and a central pressure of 920 hPa (27.17 inHg). Darian recurved southward and dissipated on August 29, without affecting any landmasses.

## Tropical Cyclone Cheneso

Tropical Cyclone Cheneso formed on January 17, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the Mozambique Channel. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on January 19, with maximum sustained winds of 120 km/h (75 mph) and a central pressure of 980 hPa (28.94 inHg). Cheneso made landfall in northern Madagascar on January 21, causing moderate damage and flooding.

## Tropical Cyclone Dingani

Tropical Cyclone Dingani formed on February 4, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on February 6, with maximum sustained winds of 110 km/h (68 mph) and a central pressure of 990 hPa (29.23 inHg). Dingani recurved southward and dissipated on February 10, without affecting any landmasses.

## Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on February 5, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on February 7, and further into a very intense tropical cyclone on February 15, with maximum sustained winds of 240 km/h (150 mph) and a central pressure of 905 hPa (26.72 inHg). Freddy made landfall in southern Mozambique on February 24, causing catastrophic damage and flooding. The cyclone then crossed into Zimbabwe and Malawi, causing further damage and loss of life.

## Tropical Cyclone Enala

Tropical Cyclone Enala formed on March 17, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the Mozambique Channel. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on March 19, with maximum sustained winds of 100 km/h (62 mph) and a central pressure of 995 hPa (29.38 inHg). Enala made landfall in southern Mozambique on March 21, causing moderate damage and flooding.

## Moderate Tropical Storm 09

Moderate Tropical Storm 09 formed on April 2, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a moderate tropical storm on April 4, with maximum sustained winds of 70 km/h (44 mph) and a central pressure of 995 hPa (29.38 inHg). The storm dissipated on April 7, without affecting any landmasses.

## Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien

Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien formed on May 10, 2023, from a tropical disturbance that had developed in the southwestern Indian Ocean. The system intensified into a tropical cyclone on May 12, and further into an intense tropical cyclone on May 15, with maximum sustained winds of 180 km/h (112 mph) and a central pressure of 935 hPa (27.61 inHg). Fabien recurved southward and dissipated on May 20, without affecting any landmasses.

# Storm names

The storm names used during the 2022-23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season were assigned by the Mauritius Meteorological Services (MMS) and the South African Weather Service (SAWS). The names were chosen from a list of names submitted by countries in the region.

# Season effects

The 2022-23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season had significant impacts on the region, particularly in Mozambique, Madagascar, and Zimbabwe. The season was marked by above-average activity, with several intense tropical cyclones and very intense tropical cyclones affecting the region. The cyclones caused widespread damage and flooding, resulting in loss of life and displacement of people.

article:
Ronald Wilson Reagan was the 40th President of the United States, serving from 1981 to 1989. Prior to his presidency, he was a Hollywood actor and served as the 33rd Governor of California from 1967 to 1975. Reagan is known for his conservative policies, his role in ending the Cold War, and his charismatic leadership style.

#Early life

Ronald Reagan was born on February 6, 1911, in Tampico, Illinois, to John Edward Reagan and Nelle Clyde Wilson Reagan. He was the younger of two sons. His father was of Irish Catholic descent, and his mother was of Scottish and English ancestry. The family moved to several different towns in Illinois before settling in Dixon, Illinois, when Reagan was nine years old.

Reagan attended Dixon High School, where he was an average student but excelled in sports, particularly football. He also developed a strong interest in acting and public speaking, which would later serve him well in his political career. After graduating from high school in 1928, Reagan attended Eureka College in Eureka, Illinois, on a partial scholarship. He majored in economics and sociology, and graduated in 1932.

#Entertainment career

##Radio and film

Reagan began his career in entertainment as a radio announcer for WOC in Davenport, Iowa. He later moved to WHO in Des Moines, Iowa, where he became a popular sports announcer. In 1937, Reagan signed a seven-year contract with Warner Bros. studios in Hollywood, California. He appeared in over 50 films during his acting career, including Knute Rockne, All American and Bedtime for Bonzo.

##Military service

In 1942, Reagan enlisted in the United States Army Reserve. He was assigned to the Army Air Forces and served as a public relations officer. Reagan was stationed in Culver City, California, and was responsible for producing training films and promoting the sale of war bonds. He was honorably discharged in 1945 with the rank of captain.

##Screen Actors Guild presidency

Reagan became a member of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) in 1937 and served as its president from 1947 to 1952 and again in 1959. During his presidency, he played a key role in shaping the union's policies and negotiating contracts with film studios.

##Marriages and children

Reagan married Jane Wyman, an actress, in 1940. The couple had two children, Maureen Elizabeth Reagan and Michael Edward Reagan. They divorced in 1948. In 1952, Reagan married Nancy Davis, also an actress. They had two children, Patricia Ann Reagan and Ronald Prescott Reagan.

##Television

Reagan began his career in television in the 1950s, hosting the General Electric Theater. He also appeared in numerous television shows and commercials, including Death Valley Days.

#Early political activities

##1966 California gubernatorial election

Reagan's entry into politics began in 1966, when he ran for Governor of California. He campaigned on a platform of reducing state spending and taxes, and won the election by a landslide.

#California governorship (1967–1975)

As governor, Reagan implemented several policies aimed at reducing state spending and taxes. He also signed several bills aimed at reducing crime and improving education. Reagan served two terms as governor, from 1967 to 1975.

#Seeking the presidency (1975–1981)

##1976 Republican primaries

Reagan ran for the Republican presidential nomination in 1976, but lost to incumbent President Gerald Ford.

##1980 election

Reagan ran for president again in 1980, and won the Republican nomination. He campaigned on a platform of reducing taxes and government spending, and won the general election in a landslide, defeating incumbent President Jimmy Carter.

#Presidency (1981–1989)

##First inauguration

Reagan was inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States on January 20, 1981. In his inaugural address, he called for a new era of American greatness and laid out his vision for reducing government spending and taxes.

##"Reaganomics" and the economy

###Taxation

Reagan signed the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, which reduced tax rates across the board. He also signed the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which eliminated many tax loopholes and deductions.

###Inflation and unemployment

Reagan implemented policies aimed at reducing inflation, including raising interest rates and reducing government spending. He also implemented policies aimed at reducing unemployment, including cutting taxes and regulations.

###Government spending

Reagan reduced government spending in several areas, including defense and social welfare programs. He also vetoed several spending bills, including a $1.6 billion education bill.

###Deregulation

Reagan implemented policies aimed at reducing government regulation of industries, including banking and energy.

###Deficits

Despite his efforts to reduce government spending, Reagan's policies led to large budget deficits. The national debt increased from $994 billion in 1980 to $2.1 trillion in 1988.

##Assassination attempt

On March 30, 1981, Reagan was shot by John Hinckley Jr. outside the Washington Hilton Hotel in Washington, D.C. Reagan recovered from his injuries and returned to duty as president.

##Supreme Court appointments

Reagan appointed several conservative judges to the Supreme Court, including Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, and Anthony Kennedy.

##Public sector labor union fights

Reagan clashed with public sector labor unions, including the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (PATCO). In 1981, he fired over 11,000 air traffic controllers who went on strike.

##Civil rights

Reagan's record on civil rights was mixed. He supported the Civil Rights Act of 1982, but also vetoed the Civil Rights Restoration Act of 1987.

##War on drugs

Reagan launched a "war on drugs" in 1982, which included increased funding for law enforcement and treatment programs.

##Escalation of the Cold War

Reagan's policies led to an escalation of the Cold War, including a buildup of the U.S. military and a series of confrontations with the Soviet Union.

##Invasion of Grenada

In 1983, Reagan authorized the invasion of Grenada, a small island nation in the Caribbean.

##1984 election

Reagan won re-election in 1984, defeating Democratic nominee Walter Mondale in a landslide.

##Response to the AIDS epidemic

Reagan's response to the AIDS epidemic was slow and inadequate, leading to widespread criticism.

##Addressing apartheid

Reagan's policies on apartheid in South Africa were mixed. He opposed economic sanctions against the apartheid regime, but also supported some measures aimed at reducing U.S. investment in South Africa.

##Libya bombing

In 1986, Reagan authorized a bombing raid against Libya, which was aimed at killing Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi.

##Iran–Contra affair

Reagan's administration was embroiled in the Iran-Contra affair, which involved the sale of arms to Iran and the use of the proceeds to fund anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua.

##The USS Stark incident

In 1987, the USS Stark was attacked by an Iraqi warplane, killing 37 U.S. sailors. Reagan's response was criticized as inadequate.

##Soviet decline and thaw in relations

Reagan's policies, including a buildup of the U.S. military and a series of confrontations with the Soviet Union, contributed to the decline of the Soviet Union and a thaw in relations between the two countries.

#Post-presidency (1989–2004)

##Support for Brady Bill

After leaving office, Reagan supported the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act, which was signed into law in 1993.

##Alzheimer's disease

In 1994, Reagan announced that he had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. He died on June 5, 2004, at the age of 93.

##Death and funeral

Reagan's funeral was held on June 11, 2004, and was attended by dignitaries from around the world.

#Legacy

##Historical reputation

Reagan's historical reputation is mixed. He is widely credited with helping to end the Cold War and boosting the U.S. economy, but his policies also led to large budget deficits and a widening income gap.

##Political influence

Reagan's influence on the Republican Party has been significant, and his policies continue to shape the party's agenda.

#Notes

This article is a comprehensive overview of the life and presidency of Ronald Reagan.

#References

This article does not include citations or references.

article:
Siege of Mariupol

The Siege of Mariupol was a prolonged military engagement that took place during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The siege, which lasted from February 24 to May 20, 2022, was one of the most intense and devastating battles of the conflict.

#Background

Mariupol, a strategic port city in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, had been a major industrial and cultural center in the country. With a pre-war population of over 450,000 people, it was a significant urban center and a key target for Russian forces seeking to capture Ukraine's coastline along the Sea of Azov.

In the months leading up to the invasion, tensions between Ukraine and Russia had escalated, with Russian forces massing along the border. Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, had warned of an impending attack, but the international community had struggled to respond effectively.

#Advances to Mariupol

##Preliminary shelling and advance on the city

On February 24, 2022, Russian forces launched a surprise invasion of Ukraine, with artillery and missile strikes hitting targets across the country. Mariupol was among the first cities to be shelled, with Russian forces seeking to soften up Ukrainian defenses before advancing on the city.

Over the next several days, Russian forces made steady gains, pushing Ukrainian troops back towards Mariupol. The city's defenses were weakened by a series of intense artillery bombardments, which destroyed homes, businesses, and critical infrastructure.

##Mariupol surrounded

By March 1, 2022, Russian forces had encircled Mariupol, cutting off the city's supply lines and trapping thousands of civilians inside. The city's defenders, a mix of Ukrainian army units, territorial defense forces, and volunteer militias, prepared for a prolonged siege.

#Urban advances

##Russian push into the city

On March 3, 2022, Russian forces launched a direct assault on Mariupol, pushing into the city's outskirts and sparking intense street fighting. Ukrainian defenders fought back, but Russian forces made steady gains, slowly pushing deeper into the city.

As the battle raged on, civilians were caught in the crossfire, with many trapped in their homes or forced to flee. The city's hospitals were quickly overwhelmed, with medical staff struggling to treat the wounded.

##Final pockets of resistance

By mid-March, Russian forces had captured much of Mariupol, but Ukrainian defenders continued to hold out in a few key areas. The city's defenders were vastly outnumbered and outgunned, but they refused to surrender.

#Resistance in the Azovstal steel plant

##Withdrawal to Azovstal

As Russian forces closed in, Ukrainian defenders withdrew to the Azovstal steel plant, a massive industrial complex that dominated the city's skyline. The plant, with its maze of tunnels, bunkers, and factories, became a fortress for the Ukrainian defenders.

2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts

The 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts was the 41st edition of the Canadian women's national curling championship, also known as the Scotties Tournament of Hearts. The event was held from February 17 to 26, 2023, at the Sandman Centre in Kamloops, British Columbia.

#Teams

The 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts featured 18 teams, representing the 10 provinces, 3 territories, and 3 wild card entries. The teams were as follows:

article:
Francis Drake
================

Sir Francis Drake was an English sea captain, privateer, navigator, and explorer who is best known for being the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe. He was a prominent figure in the Elizabethan era and played a significant role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada in 1588.

Birth and Early Years
---------------------

Francis Drake was born around 1540 in Tavistock, Devon, England, to Edmund Drake and his wife, Mary Mylwaye. He was the eldest of twelve children, and his family was of modest means. Drake's early life is not well-documented, but it is believed that he received a basic education and was raised as a Protestant.

Early Career at Sea
-------------------

Drake began his career at sea at a young age, working on ships that sailed to the Mediterranean and the coast of West Africa. In 1563, he joined his cousin, Sir John Hawkins, on a voyage to the West Indies, where they engaged in the slave trade.

### Slave Trade

Drake and Hawkins were involved in the slave trade, which was a lucrative business at the time. They transported enslaved Africans to the Spanish colonies in the Caribbean, where they were sold to plantation owners. However, Drake eventually became disillusioned with the slave trade and later spoke out against it.

### Expedition of 1572–1573

In 1572, Drake set sail on an expedition to the West Indies with two ships, the Judith and the Mary. The expedition was a success, and Drake returned to England with a significant amount of treasure.

### Rathlin Island Massacre

In 1575, Drake was involved in a massacre on Rathlin Island, off the coast of Ireland. Drake and his crew attacked the island, which was inhabited by a clan of Scottish-Irish Catholics, and killed many of the island's inhabitants.

Circumnavigation (1577–1580)
---------------------------

In 1577, Drake set sail on a voyage around the world with five ships and over 160 men. The voyage was a groundbreaking achievement and made Drake the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe.

### Execution of Thomas Doughty

During the voyage, Drake had Thomas Doughty, one of his crew members, executed for mutiny. The execution was a controversial decision, and some of Drake's crew members later questioned its legitimacy.

### Entering the Pacific (1578)

In 1578, Drake and his crew entered the Pacific Ocean through the Strait of Magellan at the tip of South America. They sailed up the coast of South America, raiding Spanish ships and towns along the way.

### Raids on Spanish American West Coast

Drake and his crew raided several Spanish towns on the west coast of South America, including Valparaíso and Callao. They also captured several Spanish ships, including the Nuestra Señora de la Victoria, which was a treasure galleon.

### Coast of California: Nova Albion (1579)

In 1579, Drake and his crew landed on the coast of California, which they named Nova Albion. They claimed the land for England and set up a settlement, which they called Nova Albion.

### Across the Pacific and Around Africa

After leaving California, Drake and his crew sailed across the Pacific Ocean and around Africa, returning to England in 1580.

### Return to Plymouth (1580)

Drake returned to Plymouth, England, in 1580, where he was greeted as a hero. He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I and given a grant of land.

### Knighthood and Arms

Drake was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I in 1581, and he was given the coat of arms of a golden ship on a blue shield. The arms were a symbol of his naval achievements and his status as a knight.

Political Career
----------------

Drake became involved in politics after his circumnavigation of the globe. He was elected as a member of parliament for Plymouth in 1581 and later became a close advisor to Queen Elizabeth I.

Great Expedition to America
-------------------------

In 1585, Drake set sail on a great expedition to America, where he raided Spanish towns and ships. The expedition was a success, and Drake returned to England with a significant amount of treasure.

Conflict with the Spanish Armada
-------------------------------

Drake played a significant role in the conflict with the Spanish Armada in 1588. He was one of the leaders of the English fleet that defeated the Spanish Armada.

### Cádiz Raid

In 1587, Drake led a raid on the Spanish port of Cádiz, where he destroyed several Spanish ships and disrupted the Spanish naval preparations.

### Defeat of the Spanish Armada

In 1588, Drake was one of the leaders of the English fleet that defeated the Spanish Armada. The defeat of the Spanish Armada was a significant victory for England and marked the beginning of English naval supremacy.

### English Armada

In 1589, Drake led the English Armada, a fleet of ships that sailed to Spain and Portugal to attack the Spanish naval bases. The expedition was a failure, and Drake was forced to return to England without achieving his objectives.

Defeats and Death
-----------------

Drake's later years were marked by a series of defeats and failures. He was defeated by the Spanish in the West Indies in 1595 and died of dysentery on January 28, 1596, off the coast of Panama.

Family and Heritage
------------------

Drake was married twice, first to Mary Newman and then to Elizabeth Sydenham. He had no children, but his family continued to play a significant role in English naval history.

Legacy and Honours
------------------

Drake's legacy is that of a great naval hero and explorer. He was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe and played a significant role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada.

### Geographical Names

Drake's name is commemorated in several geographical names, including Drake's Bay in California and Drake's Channel in the Caribbean.

The 2022 Shpageeza Cricket League, also known as the Gulbahar Shpageeza Cricket League 2022, was the eighth edition of the Shpageeza Cricket League, a domestic Twenty20 cricket tournament held in Afghanistan. The tournament was played from July 18 to August 5, 2022, at the Kabul International Cricket Stadium in Kabul.
